snippet: Limiting access to juvenile records is crucial to preventing young people from being permanently impaired by outgrown transgressions.
abstract: Editorial calls on states to shore up laws limiting access to juvenile criminal records; contends paper or digital trails can thwart young offenders long after they have left behind their youthful misbehavior; cites study by the Juvenile Law Center demonstrating scope of issue, which often causes young people to be denied jobs, housing and even admission to college.
lead_paragraph: Limiting access to juvenile records is crucial to preventing young people from being permanently impaired by outgrown transgressions.
